abstracts.cdata!:
The Project gave mixed results, for
            although its outcome is unsatisfactory given that primary
            objectives were not met, its sustainability is likely, with
            modest institutional development impacts, and, both the
            Bank, and Borrower performances show satisfactory ratings.
            Project implementation provided the following lessons. Given
            the country's broadcasting reach, the use of television
            as a medium to provide distance learning, is questionable,
            for although it may be appropriate for delivery of
            pre-school education, the plausible audience liable to be
            reached in Nigeria, is not only very limited, but those
            children to be reached are certainly not among the poorest.
            Furthermore, it is unclear how relevant the strategies of
            television (TV), and audiovisuals are for the poor, and how
            these programs could be more widely distributed. The
            alternative broadcasting solutions proposed by the project
            are very costly, unsustainable, and not likely to reach a
            sizeable, targeted population of children over a wide
            geographic area. The substantial investments in
            building/equipping the studio, and in training staff, would
            have been better used in developing a medium- to long-term
            plan for the use of these facilities, including
            privatization of the studio. Hence, the project should have
            examined the cost-effectiveness of the proposed
            interventions, through an analysis of the economies of scale
            necessary for the cost-effective use of educational TV in Nigeria.
